message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The new drug added is a selective α2 adrenergic receptor agonist, which acts to decrease peripheral sympathetic outflow, leading to a decrease in blood pressure. Negative inotropic effect on the heart and vasodilation of peripheral veins and arteries are not the mechanisms of this specific drug.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The new drug is a selective α2 adrenergic receptor agonist, which means it can decrease sympathetic outflow and thus decrease blood pressure. Negative inotropic effect on the heart and vasodilation of peripheral veins are not likely to be the mechanism of action, and vasodilation of peripheral arteries may decrease blood pressure, but it is not the primary mechanism of action in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and elevated blood pressure suggest hypertension. Adding a selective α2 adrenergic receptor agonist will decrease peripheral sympathetic outflow, which will result in decreased blood pressure. The other options are not consistent with the drug’s mechanism of action.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The drug is a selective α2 adrenergic receptor agonist, which means it decreases sympathetic outflow, leading to decreased vasoconstriction and decreased blood pressure. Options A and B are related to the heart and veins respectively, while option C is related to arteries, but the drug acts specifically on α2 receptors and decreases sympathetic outflow.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The new drug added is a selective α2 adrenergic receptor agonist, which decreases peripheral sympathetic outflow, leading to decreased vascular resistance and blood pressure. The other options are not directly related to the mechanism of action of this drug.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The new drug that was added is a selective α2 adrenergic receptor agonist. Activation of α2 adrenergic receptors in the brainstem can decrease peripheral sympathetic outflow, thus decreasing blood pressure. Option A is incorrect because negative inotropic effect on the heart will decrease cardiac output and can exacerbate hypertension. Option B is incorrect because vasodilation of peripheral veins will not significantly decrease blood pressure. Option C is incorrect because vasodilation of peripheral arteries may decrease blood pressure, but it is not the primary mechanism of action of this drug.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The addition of a selective α2 adrenergic receptor agonist suggests that the drug decreases peripheral sympathetic outflow, which can lead to a decrease in blood pressure. The other options are not associated with α2 adrenergic receptor agonists.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has essential hypertension, which suggests increased sympathetic tone. A selective α2 adrenergic receptor agonist can decrease peripheral sympathetic outflow, leading to a reduction in blood pressure. Negative inotropic effect on the heart may result in reduced cardiac output but not necessarily lowered blood pressure. Vasodilation of peripheral veins only redistribute blood flow, and vasodilation of peripheral arteries alone may not be effective in reducing blood pressure.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The addition of a selective α2 adrenergic receptor agonist suggests that the drug is decreasing peripheral sympathetic outflow, which can help lower blood pressure. Option (A) is incorrect because negative inotropic effect on the heart can decrease cardiac output and worsen hypertension. Option (B) is incorrect as selective α2 agonists mainly affect arteriolar resistance, whereas veins contribute very little to total arterial resistance. Option (C) is incorrect because peripheral arterial vasodilation can lead to reflex tachycardia and increased cardiac output, which can worsen hypertension.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The selective α2 adrenergic receptor agonist decreases sympathetic outflow, leading to decreased peripheral resistance and lowered blood pressure. None of the other options are associated with α2 adrenergic receptors.
